unnormalised: Someone asked me about the best way to book train tickets in India, and honestly, it's a bit of a circus, but once you get the hang of it, it's not so bad. Firstly, you gotta get yourself an IRCTC account. That's the Indian Railways Catering and Tourism Corporation. Just Google "IRCTC registration," and you'll find the link. Remember, you'll need your mobile no. and email id handy for verification.
normalised: Someone asked me about the best way to book train tickets in India, and honestly, it's a bit of a circus, but once you get the hang of it, it's not so bad. Firstly, you gotta get yourself an I-R-C-T-C account. That's the Indian Railways Catering and Tourism Corporation. Just Google "I-R-C-T-C registration," and you'll find the link. Remember, you'll need your mobile number and email I-D handy for verification.

unnormalised: Now, booking itself. The IRCTC website or app (I prefer the app, much easier on the go) is where the magic happens. Type in your starting station (e.g., Mumbai CST) and your destination (e.g., New Delhi), along with the date of travel (say, 25/12/2024). Then, hit search. You'll see a list of trains with different classes like SL (Sleeper Class), 3A (3rd AC), 2A (2nd AC), 1A (1st AC), and even CC (Chair Car) if it's a shorter daytime journey.
normalised: Now, booking itself. The I-R-C-T-C website or app (I prefer the app, much easier on the go) is where the magic happens. Type in your starting station (e.g., Mumbai C-S-T) and your destination (e.g., New Delhi), along with the date of travel (say, twenty fifth December two thousand and twenty four). Then, hit search. You'll see a list of trains with different classes like S-L (Sleeper Class), three A (third A-C), two A (second A-C), one A (first A-C), and even C-C (Chair Car) if it's a shorter daytime journey.

unnormalised: The key is to book early, especially if you're travelling during peak season like Diwali or summer vacations. Tickets open 120 days in advance at 8:00 AM sharp for AC classes and 11:00 AM for Sleeper class. Trust me, those tickets vanish faster than free chai at a railway station! So, set a reminder on your phone.
normalised: The key is to book early, especially if you're travelling during peak season like Diwali or summer vacations. Tickets open one hundred and twenty days in advance at eight zero zero A-M sharp for A-C classes and eleven zero zero A-M for Sleeper class. Trust me, those tickets vanish faster than free chai at a railway station! So, set a reminder on your phone.

unnormalised: If the tickets are sold out (which is highly likely!), don't despair! There's something called a "Waitlist." You can still book a ticket, but your confirmation depends on cancellations. The lower your waitlist number (e.g., WL 1, WL 2), the better your chances. You can check your PNR status (a 10-digit number printed on your ticket or booking confirmation) on the IRCTC website or various other apps. There's also RAC (Reservation Against Cancellation), where you get a seat, but it might be shared.

There's also R-A-C (Reservation Against Cancellation), where you get a seat, but it might be shared.

unnormalised: A quicker but often more expensive option is Tatkal booking. Tatkal bookings open 1 day before the journey, at 10:00 AM for AC classes and 11:00 AM for Sleeper class. Be warned, the competition is fierce, and the prices are higher. Plus, it's non-refundable.
normalised: A quicker but often more expensive option is Tatkal booking. Tatkal bookings open one day before the journey, at ten zero zero A-M for A-C classes and eleven zero zero A-M for Sleeper class. Be warned, the competition is fierce, and the prices are higher. Plus, it's non-refundable.

unnormalised: For payment, you can use credit cards, debit cards, net banking, UPI (like PhonePe or Google Pay), or even wallets. Once you've paid, you'll get a confirmation SMS and email. Remember to download the ticket onto your phone; you can show that to the ticket checker (TC) along with a valid photo ID (Aadhaar, Voter ID, PAN card, etc.).

Remember to download the ticket onto your phone; you can show that to the ticket checker (T-C) along with a valid photo I-D (Aadhaar, Voter I-D, P-A-N card, etcetera).

unnormalised: Also, keep an eye out for special trains or festival specials that IRCTC runs during peak seasons. They often add extra coaches too to existing trains during festivals. You can usually find info about them on the IRCTC website under "News and Announcements".

unnormalised: One last tip: if you're a senior citizen (60+ for men, 58+ for women), you're eligible for a discount on train tickets. Just make sure to select the senior citizen option while booking and carry your age proof with you. The percentage discount varies, usually around 40-50%. Happy travels, and don't forget to grab some samosas on the platform!
